channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: ICE declares millions of undocumented immigrants no longer eligible for bond hearings
item.description: A memo sent by ICE’s acting director and obtained by The Washington Post instructs officers to hold immigrants who entered the country illegally “for the duration of their removal proceedings,” which can take months or years. Lawyers say the policy will apply to millions of immigrants who crossed the U.S.-Mexico border over the past few decades, including under former president Joe Biden.

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump administration to proceed with deep cuts at Education Department, for now
item.description: The justices lifted a temporary lower-court ruling that prevented Trump officials from slashing more than a third of the department’s more than 4,100 workers and shifting some of its functions to the states and other departments.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Distance from critical mom comes with guilt for not trying harder
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Distance from critical mom comes with guilt for not trying harder

item.title: Trump threatens new tariffs and sanctions on Russia and announces European countries will buy U.S. weapons to send to Ukraine
item.description: President Donald Trump and NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte made the announcement Monday during a meeting at the White House. The move to increase support for Kyiv follows Trump’s frustration with Russian President Vladimir Putin’s continued bombardment of Ukraine.

item.title: Quite the discovery in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Camp Mystic waited over an hour to evacuate after receiving ‘life threatening’ flood alert
item.description:
Interviews with nearly two dozen counselors, emergency officials, parents and experts reveal that as Camp Mystic Executive Director Dick Eastland conferred with family members and other employees about how to respond to the alert, the camp descended into chaos as the river rose to record levels.
Water was at least four feet high around many of the cabins, a Washington Post analysis found.

item.title: MAGA warning. ICE deportations. Israeli strike. Texas floods. Air quality. Jannik Sinner. Dinosaur bones. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: How the Trump assassination attempt supercharged beliefs in a divine right of MAGA
item.description: President Donald Trump and many of his followers have described the rally shooting on July 13, 2024, as a mass spiritual awakening, promoting the belief that Trump enacts God’s will.

item.title: After franchise upheaval, Washington Nationals select infielder Eli Willits with the No. 1 pick in the MLB draft
item.description: The selection of Willits, a 17-year-old high school shortstop from Oklahoma, came just one week after Washington fired its longtime general manager, Mike Rizzo. Mike DeBartolo has taken the helm as interim GM of the Nationals, who also fired manager Dave Martinez. The Nationals previously used No. 1 picks on Bryce Harper and Stephen Strasburg, setting a high bar for their choice this year.

item.title: A clinic blames its closing on Trump’s Medicaid cuts. Some patients don’t buy it.
item.description: A clinic in rural Nebraska has become a political flash point after tying its pending closure to Trump’s law cutting Medicaid. Residents of Curtis — a one-stoplight town in deep-red farm country — are sorry to lose the clinic but skeptical of the rationale.

item.title: Jannik Sinner wins first Wimbledon championship and fourth Grand Slam title, denying Carlos Alcaraz a third straight victory there
item.description: It was the first appearance in the Wimbledon final for Sinner, the 23-year-old Italian who avenged his loss to Alcaraz at last month's French Open. He and Alcaraz, a 22-year-old from Spain, have combined to win the last seven men’s Grand Slam titles.

item.title: National Park Service tells its gift shops to remove anything that ‘disparages Americans’
item.description: Park staff were ordered to report any retail items containing content that “inappropriately disparages Americans past or living” or that includes “matters unrelated to the beauty, abundance or grandeur” of a natural feature in its description. The move is part of the administration’s wider campaign to scrub federal institutions of “corrosive ideology” recognizing historical racism and sexism.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Six less-expensive beach vacations in the U.S., from Georgia to California
item.description: Even if we’re not exploring the Mediterranean or living it up at an all-inclusive resort in Mexico, we still crave the beach — especially one relatively close to home that won’t eat up our vacation funds. We asked professional travel planners for help identifying these top budget picks.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: ICE memo outlines plan to deport migrants to countries where they are not citizens
item.description: Federal immigration officers may deport immigrants with as little as six hours’ notice to countries other than their own even if officials have not provided any assurances that the new arrivals will be safe from persecution or torture, a top official said in a memo this week. The dramatic shift in policy could result in thousands of people being sent to places where they lack family ties or even a common language.

item.title: He knows he was adopted from South Korea. When he started digging into his past, red flags emerged.
item.description: For years, Aaron Grzegorczyk thought his birth mother had left him at a South Korean clinic in 1988. A recent report found the country had allowed a “profit-driven” adoption “industry” to flourish for decades, leaving Grzegorczyk wondering whether he’s yet another victim.

item.title: Tech billionaire Marc Andreesen says colleges will ‘pay the price’ for DEI, according to private group chat with Trump officials
item.description: Andreessen co-founded one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent venture capital firms, Andreessen Horowitz, which embraced Donald Trump’s candidacy last year. While Elon Musk was the most visible tech mogul in Trump’s orbit until he split with the president, Andreessen has quietly helped shape the administration’s hiring and policy decisions.

item.title: Iga Swiatek defeats Amanda Anisimova to win first Wimbledon championship and sixth Grand Slam title
item.description: The 24-year old Swiatek, a former world No. 1 from Poland, has never lost a Grand Slam championship match. It was the first appearance in a Grand Slam final for the American Anisimova, who upset top-seeded Aryna Sabalenka in the semifinals.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: I dread my bigoted mother-in-law’s weekly lunches
item.description: Ask Sahaj: I dread my bigoted mother-in-law’s weekly lunches

item.title: In the dark, a teen counselor at Camp Mystic led 16 girls to safety: ‘Get ready to climb’
item.description: Ainslie Bashara, 19, had arrived a week earlier for a month-long stay. She’d met campers from the Giggle Box cabin just five days earlier but had already grown devoted to them. Together they braved the relentless Texas floodwaters.

item.title: Trump says he’s ready to slap 30% tariffs on imports from Mexico and European Union starting Aug. 1
item.description: The latest move is likely to disrupt relationships following weeks of negotiations with two of the United States’ largest trading partners. Over the past week, President Donald Trump has sent letters to various world leaders about new levies he is readying to impose on imports.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Federal judge orders halt to Trump administration’s indiscriminate immigration stops and arrests in California
item.description: A federal judge ordered the Trump administration to stop patrolling and rounding up individuals without reasonable justification, including basing arrests on racial profiling, and to stop denying access to lawyers, saying the tactics are unconstitutional.

item.title: A Texas county didn't use its most powerful and far-reaching alert system as floods grew deadly on July 4
item.description: A Washington Post examination found Kerr County officials eventually sent text-message alerts on the morning of July 4 to some residents. But even as conditions deteriorated, they did not activate a more forceful tool that would have sounded an alarm on cellphones throughout the river valley.

item.title: David Gergen dies at 83. The consummate political insider held communications jobs under Nixon, Ford, Reagan and Clinton.
item.description: Gergen, a conservative-leaning centrist, helped craft and protect the image of four presidents as a senior White House communications adviser and held high-profile jobs in TV punditry and academia.

item.title: Unexpected fuel cutoff preceded Air India plane crash, preliminary report says
item.description: Indian investigators’ initial findings suggest that both engines stopped receiving fuel shortly after takeoff, but a final determination by the government’s Aircraft Accident Investigation Bureau into the cause of the crash is likely more than a year away.

item.title: Meet the Trump staffers behind the push to overhaul higher education
item.description: Shaped by experiences as ideological minorities on liberal campuses, these officials are targeting their alma maters.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: Father-in-law destroyed the garden I inherited from my dying mom
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: Father-in-law destroyed the garden I inherited from my dying mom

item.title: This Army combat veteran may have stopped Trump’s would-be assassin. Now he’s telling his story.
item.description: Butler County SWAT team operator Aaron Zaliponi fired the “ninth shot” at Donald Trump’s Pennsylvania rally last July. He believes it hit the shooter’s rifle, but one year later, the significance of his quick action is still unresolved.

item.title: State Department is firing more than 1,300 employees by email in downsizing plan
item.description: The move has come under criticism from current and former diplomats who say the cuts will degrade America’s standing in the world and curb U.S. soft power.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Trump shooting anniversary. Texas visit. Federal layoffs. Birthright citizenship. Wimbledon. AI videos. Jan. 6 show. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump announces 35% tariffs on Canada, injecting fresh turmoil into a strained bilateral relationship
item.description: The levy sets back Prime Minister Mark Carney’s efforts to negotiate a new economic partnership with the U.S. In a letter, President Donald Trump said the announcement was because of Canada's tariffs on the U.S. and in response to the incoming flow of fentanyl, though there is little evidence the drug is being smuggled across the northern border in significant quantities.

item.title: Firings without explanation across Justice Dept., FBI have created climate of fear, people familiar with the matter say
item.description: The Trump administration is firing and pushing out employees in multiple departments, creating rampant speculation and worry over who might be terminated next, according to multiple people with knowledge of the removals, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to avoid retribution. The terminations appear more individually targeted than the high-profile ousters of senior Justice Department and FBI officials in the early months of President Donald Trump’s second term.

item.title: A band of innovators reimagines the spy game for a world with no cover
item.description: For spies, there is literally no place to hide. Millions of cameras around the world record every movement and catalogue it forever. Every action leaves digital tracks that can be studied and linked with others.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Daughter-in-law needs help processing child’s new gender identity
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Daughter-in-law needs help processing child’s new gender identity

item.title: Judge places new block on Trump’s birthright citizenship ban nationwide, in line with Supreme Court ruling
item.description: A federal judge in New Hampshire issued the temporary injunction after agreeing to certify a class-action lawsuit against President Donald Trump’s administration on behalf of U.S.-born children or future children whose automatic citizenship could be jeopardized by the president’s executive order, lawyers for the plaintiffs said. The Supreme Court ruled last month that such nationwide orders apply only in limited circumstances, including class-action lawsuits.

item.title: Tennis fans deserve better than John McEnroe in the broadcast booth, our columnist writes
item.description: McEnroe maintains his grip on tennis microphones, despite a refusal to work at his craft or study the modern game, columnist Sally Jenkins writes. Tennis is a gorgeous game deserving of more eloquence than this.

item.title: Actually, you don’t need to remove these in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your daily points.

item.title: Trump vs. Brazil. Federal firings. Ukraine-Russia shift. Tunnel collapse. Texas search. X CEO. French national hero. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Photos and videos show how the Texas flooding surged in a matter of hours and how rescues unfolded
item.description: See how water from the swollen Guadalupe River surged into Camp Mystic and other parts of Kerr County, and how people have searched for and recovered victims.

item.title: Trump announces 50% tariffs on Brazil starting Aug. 1, citing its treatment of former president Jair Bolsonaro
item.description: President Donald Trump scrambled his trade agenda and delivered a broadside against the government of Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva over its treatment of Bolsonaro, the former leader who is on trial for trying to overthrow the government.

item.title: Flooding and severe thunderstorm watches issued, with worst weather expected toward evening
item.description: The National Weather Service is cautioning that storms could produce locally significant flooding, damaging wind gusts and isolated large hail. Storms are expected to be heavier and more widespread than Tuesday’s.

item.title: Think surprise medical bills are in the past? Surprise!
item.description: The surprise medical bills just keep coming

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Gay man avoids homophobic brother-in-law. But at what cost?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Gay man avoids homophobic brother-in-law. But at what cost?

item.title: Linda Yaccarino steps down as CEO of Elon Musk’s X. The resignation comes a day after the Grok chatbot’s antisemitic outbursts.
item.description: Yaccarino announced her departure from the social media site in a post on X, one day after Grok made posts referencing Hitler that were later deleted. She did not provide a reason for her decision. She was hired by Musk to run the social network formerly known as Twitter in 2023, after he acquired the company for $44 billion.

item.title: Dining chat: Can I tip less now that Trump's bill has mostly done away with taxes on gratuity?
item.description: Dining chat: Can I tip less now that Trump's bill has mostly done away with taxes on gratuity?

item.title: Trump’s moves on immigration, Ukraine and the Epstein case are roiling the MAGA base
item.description: Some of his most loyal supporters fear President Donald Trump is going back on promises crucial to his political movement. White House officials disputed the idea that the unrest seriously threatens Trump’s support.

item.title: Red spots in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.
